title: Drawing, A Sepulchral monument of Henry Cardinal York (1725-1807) and Charles Edward Stuart, the “Young Pretender” (1720-1788), 1788–1793
title_raw: A Sepulchral monument of Henry Cardinal York (1725-1807) and Charles Edward Stuart, the “Young Pretender” (1720-1788)
markings: Watermark: crowned beehive showing “HONIG” – in the base, over “JHZ”
creditline: Museum purchase through gift of various donors
description: The cardinal seated at the left holds the right arm of his brother who is clad in the attire of a classical warrior, and points with his right forefinger to heaven. The group is displayed on top of a sepulchral chamber against the convex back wall of a side chapel. Upon the chamber lean “CHARITY” with three children, at left “WAR” holding a sword and trampling of the tablets of the Law and a pair of scales at right. The setting shows a vaulted side chapel; the back wall is shaped as an apse with framing lines throughout.

tombstone.epitaph: Drawing, A Sepulchral monument of Henry Cardinal York (1725-1807) and Charles Edward Stuart, the “Young Pretender” (1720-1788), 1788–1793; ITALY & FRANCE; pencil, pen, wash, chinese ink; H x W: 66.2 × 44 cm (26 1/16 × 17 5/16 in.); Museum purchase through gift of various donors; 1901-39-2509
